request_pathways.name: Authorization for Release of Medical Information

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a generic system-wide authorization form, prints and completes it by hand, and submits via fax, mail, or in-person; a portal redirect is noted at the top of the form.

red_flags: Vague fee warning without amounts or distinction between patient-access and third-party release fees
Broad liability waiver releasing Banner Health from any legal responsibility for disclosure
bright_spots: Prominent patient portal redirect at the top of the form directs patients to self-service access before the paper process
Recent revision date (06/2025) demonstrates active form maintenance
Granular per-category opt-out checkboxes for sensitive information (HIV, behavioral health, substance abuse, genetic testing)
Explicit statement that treatment will not be conditioned on signing the authorization

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation or a simple search — the form was returned immediately by web search and is published under the patients/medical-records section of bannerhealth.com with no bot blocking or login walls.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the PDF has zero fillable fields, requiring patients to print, handwrite all fields, and sign by hand; fax submission is available but the form itself offers no digital completion capability.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — the form has clear section headers, logical flow, and granular record-type selection, but the opening paragraph about third-party directives is dense regulatory jargon and there is a grammatical error in the exclusion instructions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the form is a generic authorization for all releases with a 'Self' checkbox option, but does not distinguish patient access rights from third-party release; the portal callout is helpful but the form itself is not patient-access-specific.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: Minor ambiguities but nothing that would materially impede a patient — the form correctly states non-conditioning of treatment, right to revoke, and right to a copy, but the fee disclosure is vague and the broad liability waiver goes beyond HIPAA requirements.

overall.summary: Banner Health provides easily findable and well-maintained forms with good content design, but the non-fillable PDF, generic authorization pathway, and vague fee disclosure keep it in the average range for patient experience.
